arm_group.description: This is an ultrasound-based new technique using Acoustic Radiation Force Impulse (ARFI)-Derived Shear Wave Velocity Imaging in detecting bladder wall thickness and fibrosis in the urinary bladder of pediatric patients.

brief_summary.textblock:
Urinary bladder fibrosis is relatively uncommon in children. Traditionally, the presence of
      urinary bladder fibrosis has been confirmed directly with bladder biopsy or using urodynamic
      testing.  We're will use ARFI (acoustic radiation force impulse)-derived shear wave
      velocities to hopefully identify the presence of urinary bladder wall fibrosis.  We
      hypothesize that shear wave velocities obtained within the bladder wall will increase with
      increasing evidence of fibrosis.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          1. 18 years of age or younger

          2. Your physician has ordered urodynamic testing -

        Exclusion Criteria:

        None

        -

intervention.description: An ultrasound based scan using acoustic radiation force impulse-derived shear wave velocities to obtain images of the urinary bladder.  The research ultrasound scan will take approximately 10 to 15 minutes to complete.

clinical_study.official_title: Evaluation of Pediatric Urinary Bladder Wall Thickening and Fibrosis Using Acoustic Radiation Force Impulse (ARFI)-Derived Shear Wave Velocities

authority: United States: Food and Drug Administration

primary_outcome.description: That the measurements of the bladder wall thickness determined by the ARFI-Derived Shear Wave Velocities confirm bladder wall thickening and fibrosis.

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.study_design: Endpoint Classification: Safety/Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Single Group Assignment, Masking: Open Label, Primary Purpose: Diagnostic
